an4.191:1.1: “Mendicants, you can expect four benefits when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.
an4.191:1.3: Take a mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:1.4: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
an4.191:1.5: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.
an4.191:1.6: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:1.7: Being happy there, passages of the teaching come back to them.
an4.191:1.9: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:1.10: This is the first benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.
an4.191:2.1: Take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:2.2: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
an4.191:2.3: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.
an4.191:2.4: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:2.5: Though they’re happy there, passages of the teaching don’t come back to them.
an4.191:2.6: However, a mendicant with psychic powers, who has achieved mastery of the mind, teaches Dhamma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:2.8: ‘I used to lead the spiritual life in this same teaching and training.’
an4.191:2.10: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:2.11: Suppose a person was skilled in the sound of drums.
an4.191:2.12: While traveling along a road they hear the sound of drums.
an4.191:2.13: They wouldn’t have any doubts or uncertainties about whether
an4.191:2.14: that was the sound of drums or not.
an4.191:2.15: They’d just conclude, ‘That’s the sound of drums.’
an4.191:2.16: In the same way, take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching …
an4.191:2.19: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …
an4.191:2.25: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:2.26: This is the second benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.
an4.191:3.1: Take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:3.2: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
an4.191:3.3: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.
an4.191:3.4: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:3.5: But passages of the teaching don’t come back to them when they’re happy, nor does a mendicant with psychic powers … teach Dhamma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:3.6: However, a god teaches Dhamma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:3.8: ‘I used to lead the spiritual life in this same teaching and training.’
an4.191:3.10: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:3.11: Suppose a person was skilled in the sound of horns.
an4.191:3.12: While traveling along a road they hear the sound of horns.
an4.191:3.13: They wouldn’t have any doubt about whether
an4.191:3.14: that was the sound of horns or not.
an4.191:3.15: They’d just conclude, ‘That’s the sound of horns.’
an4.191:3.16: In the same way, take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching …
an4.191:3.19: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …
an4.191:3.25: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:3.26: This is the third benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.
an4.191:4.1: Take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching—
an4.191:4.2: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
an4.191:4.3: They’ve followed those teachings by ear, reinforced them by recitation, examined them by the mind, and well comprehended them theoretically.
an4.191:4.4: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods.
an4.191:4.5: But passages of the teaching don’t come back to them when they’re happy, and neither a mendicant with psychic powers … nor a god teaches Dhamma to the assembly of gods.
an4.191:4.6: But a being who has been reborn spontaneously reminds another such being:
an4.191:4.7: ‘Do you remember, good sir? Do you remember where we used to lead the spiritual life?’
an4.191:4.11: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:4.12: Suppose there were two friends who had played together in the sand.
an4.191:4.13: Some time or other they’d meet.
an4.191:4.14: And one friend would say to the other:
an4.191:4.15: ‘Do you remember this, friend? Do you remember that, friend?’
an4.191:4.18: In the same way, take another mendicant who memorizes the teaching …
an4.191:4.21: But they die unmindful and are reborn in one of the orders of gods. …
an4.191:4.28: but then that being quickly reaches distinction.
an4.191:4.29: This is the fourth benefit you can expect when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.
an4.191:4.30: You can expect these four benefits when the teachings have been followed by ear, reinforced by recitation, examined by the mind, and well comprehended theoretically.”
